title: How to Make Ghee Rice

steps.headline: Soak and drain the rice.
steps.description: Place the basmati rice in a glass bowl and completely cover it with water. Allow the rice to soak for 20 minutes before draining away the water. Soak the rice in approximately 3 cups (750 ml) of cool water, keeping it completely submerged the entire time. Near the end of the soaking time, use your hands to move the rice around while still submerged. As you do this, the water should become notably cloudy. Pour the contents of the bowl through a fine metal colander. Drain the water and keep the rice in the colander.

steps.headline: Rinse the rice.
steps.description: Place the the colander of rice beneath the sink and run water over it for 30 to 60 seconds, or until the water draining beneath it runs clear.

steps.headline: Boil the rice in water.
steps.description: Place the clean rice in a heavy-bottom stockpot and cover it with 2 cups (500 ml) cool, fresh water. Set the pan on your stove and bring the water to a boil over medium-high heat. Gently stir the rice as the water heats to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pan. Do so slowly to avoid breaking the grains.

steps.headline: Add the salt and continue cooking.
steps.description: As soon as the water reaches a boil, sprinkle the contents with salt and turn off the heat. Cover the pan and continue cooking the rice until it becomes tender. Do not remove the pan from the stove. The rice should continue cooking in the residual heat. The rice should finish cooking in approximately 15 minutes. Do not remove the lid or stir the contents of the pan during this time.

steps.headline: Set aside.
steps.description: Gently fluff the cooked rice with a fork. Set it aside while you continue preparing the rest of the recipe. Ideally, the rice should cool to room temperature before you add it to the other ingredients.

steps.headline: Heat the ghee.
steps.description: Place the ghee in a skillet or wok. Set the pan on the stove over medium-high heat. Allow the ghee to heat for at least 30 to 60 seconds. It should become somewhat glossier and more fluid, making it easier to spread across the bottom of the pan. Do not allow the ghee to start smoking, however.

steps.headline: Fry the cashews and raisins.
steps.description: Place the cashews and raisins in the hot ghee. Stir fry for several minutes, or until the nuts look evenly toasted on all sides. Once the cashews and raisins are ready, transfer them to another plate using a slotted spoon, leaving as much ghee in the pan as possible. Keep the nuts and raisins warm while you continue working.

steps.headline: Add the garlic, onion, and whole spices.
steps.description: Place the sliced onions, minced garlic, cinnamon, cardamom, cloves, bay leaf, and star anise in the remaining ghee. Fry the seasonings, stirring frequently, for about 5 minutes. During this time, the garlic and onion should both become golden-brown in color. The bay leaf should turn crisp and the whole spices may make gentle popping noises.

steps.headline: Fry the rice.
steps.description: Add the cooked basmati rice to the pan. Fry for 2 to 4 minutes, stirring frequently. As you stir the rice, evenly mix the ghee, garlic, onions, and spices into the grains. Work carefully to avoid breaking the grains. When ready, the rice should have a slightly darker hue but should not turn fully brown.

steps.headline: Garnish with cashews and raisins.
steps.description: Transfer the rice to serving plates and garnish each serving with the reserved cashews and raisins. Eat the ghee rice while it's still hot. You can also serve the rice with fried onions, vegetable korma, or spicy gravy.

steps.headline: Rinse the rice.
steps.description: Place the rice in a fine metal colander. Rinse it under running water until the water draining beneath the colander runs clear. If you do not have a colander or running water, you can drain it using an alternate method. Place the rice in a glass dish and cover it with water. Use your hands to gently squeeze and stir the grains, making the water turn cloudy. Drain the dirty water and repeat the entire process, once or twice more, or until the water remains clear.

steps.headline: Soak the rice.
steps.description: Place the rinsed rice in a glass bowl and cover it with 3 cups (750 ml) of cool, clean water. Allow the rice to soak for 20 minutes. Soaking the rice should make it softer and less sticky. It should also reduce the overall cooking time. After you finish soaking the rice, drain and discard the water. Set the rice aside until it's time to add it to the rest of the ingredients.

steps.headline: Heat the ghee in the pressure cooker.
steps.description: Place the ghee in a pressure cooker and warm it over medium-high heat. Ideally, you should use a pressure cooker with an approximate 3.5-qt (3.5-L) capacity when preparing this much ghee rice. Allow the ghee to heat for 30 to 60 seconds before continuing. It should be easy to turn the pressure cooker and coat the bottom with the ghee once it becomes adequately warm.

steps.headline: Saute the whole spices.
steps.description: Add the cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, peppercorns, and bay leaf to the hot ghee. Cook for several seconds, stirring constantly. The spices should begin to sputter and release stronger scents, but you should not allow them to burn or deepen in color. The edges of the bay leaf may begin turning up, however.

steps.headline: Fry the nuts and raisins.
steps.description: Add the cashews and raisins to the pressure cooker. Cook, stirring frequently, for another minute. When ready, the nuts should look toasty brown and the raisins should become somewhat puffy.

steps.headline: Add the onion, chilli, garlic, and ginger.
steps.description: Place the prepared onion, chilli pepper, garlic, and ginger in the pressure cooker. Cook, stirring frequently, for another 1 to 2 minutes. Allow the ginger and onion to change color. Both should become more golden or lightly browned, but do not allow either one to burn. Frequent stirring should minimize the risk of burning.

steps.headline: Mix in the rice.
steps.description: Add the drained rice to the pressure cooker. Reduce the heat to low and saute for about 2 minutes. Stir the rice to coat the grains with the ghee and other seasonings. Occasional stirring should also prevent the rice from sticking to the pressure cooker, but you should work carefully to avoid breaking any grains.

steps.headline: Add the water and salt.
steps.description: Pour 2 cups (500 ml) of water over the rice. Sprinkle the contents with salt.

steps.headline: Cover and cook until tender.
steps.description: Close and seal the pressure cooker. After achieving full pressure, cook the ghee rice for 10 minutes. When you close and seal the pressure cooker, switch the heat to high. As soon as steam pours out from the vent, place the pressure regulator or weight on the nozzle and switch the heat back down to low. Continue cooking for 10 minutes before turning the heat off completely.

steps.headline: Release the pressure.
steps.description: Wait for the pressure cooker to naturally release the built-up pressure. Once this happens, carefully open the lid and fluff the rice with a fork. Do not open the pressure cooker before the pressure drops. It should usually take 5 to 8 minutes for the device to release the built-up pressure.

steps.headline: Serve hot.
steps.description: Stir the rice and transfer it to individual serving dishes. Enjoy while it's still hot.
